contentrichtext.text: [[File:Mirabello Cavalori 001.jpg|thumb|250px|''Lavinia at the Altar'' (''ca.'' 1565) by [[Mirabello Cavalori]], depicting the moment at which Lavinia's hair blazes as an omen of war but ultimate reconciliation]] {{Other uses|Lavinia (disambiguation)}} In [[Roman mythology]], '''Lavinia''' ({{lang-la|Lāuīnĭa}}) is the daughter of [[Latinus]] and [[Amata]] and the last wife of [[Aeneas]]. Lavinia, the only child of the king and "ripe for marriage", had been courted by many [[Ausones|men in Ausonia]] who hoped to become the king of [[Latium]]. [[Turnus]], ruler of the [[Rutuli]], was the most likely of the suitors, having the favor of Queen Amata. King Latinus is later warned by his father [[Faunus]] in a [[dream oracle]] that his daughter is not to marry a [[Latini|Latin]]. <blockquote>"Propose no Latin alliance for your daughter,<br /> Son of mine; distrust the bridal chamber<br /> Now prepared. Men from abroad will come<br /> And be your sons by marriage. Blood so mingled<br /> Lifts our name starward. Children of that stock<br /> Will see all earth turned Latin at their feet,<br /> Governed by them, as far as on his rounds<br /> The Sun looks down on Ocean, East or West."<ref>''Aeneid'' 7.96–101, as translated by [[Robert Fitzgerald]].</ref></blockquote> Lavinia has what is perhaps her most, or only, memorable moment in Book 7 of the ''[[Aeneid]]'', lines 69–83: during sacrifice at the altars of the gods, Lavinia's hair catches fire, an omen promising glorious days to come for Lavinia and war for all Latins. Aeneas and Lavinia had one son, [[Silvius (mythology)|Silvius]]. Aeneas named the city [[Lavinium]] for her. According to an account by [[Livy]], [[Ascanius]] was the son of Aeneas and Lavinia; and she ruled the [[Latins]] as a [[power behind the throne]], for [[Ascanius]] was too young to rule. == In other works == In [[Ursula K. Le Guin]]'s 2008 novel ''[[Lavinia (novel)|Lavinia]]'', the character of Lavinia and her relationship with Aeneas is expanded and elaborated, giving insight into the life of a king's daughter in ancient Italy. Le Guin employs a self-conscious narrative device in having Lavinia as the first-person narrator know that she would not have a life without [[Virgil]], who, being the writer of the ''Aeneid'', is thus her creator. Lavinia, in Shakespeare's ''Titus Andronicus'', is the daughter of Titus, and is raped and butchered by the sons of the Gothic queen.<ref>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Titus_Andronicus#Characters</ref> Lavinia also appears with her father Latinus in [[Dante]]'s ''[[Divine Comedy]]'', ''Inferno'', Canto IV, lines 125–126. == References == * [[Virgil]]. ''[[Aeneid]]''. VII. * [[Livy]], ''[[Ab Urbe Condita]]'' Book 1. {{reflist}} [[Category:Characters in the Aeneid]] [[Category:Roman mythology]]
